answers.answer: The answer to that is a resounding YES........You need to get her Free T3 and Free T4 levels checked, along with thyroid antibodies - TPOab and TGab.TSH is actually a pituitary hormone and is not totally indicative of what the thyroid is doing.  The "free T's" are the actual thyroid hormones in the blood and are what is readily available for the body to use.  Without knowing what those levels are, you really have no idea what's going on.The antibody tests will determine if there's an autoimmune disease present.  With type I diabetes, which is also autoimmune, it wouldn't surprise me a bit for her to have another (or even more) autoimmune.  I, personally, have 2 - Hashimoto's Thyroiditis and pernicious anemia (b12 deficiency).It would also be good to have an ultra sound to see if there are any nodules on the thyroid.If you can't get her current endo to check anything further, it might be good to find a different endo.  A lot of endos specialize in diabetes, not thyroid, (even though they are both dealing with the endocrine system) so you need someone who is willing to get off the old thinking that TSH is the "end all, be all" of thyroid diagnosis.By the way -- just out of curiosity, what was her TSH?  The new range is 0.3-3.0, even though some labs (and doctors) still go by the old ranges, so if her TSH is in the lower part of the range, I'd definitely seek further help.Good luck
